UK survives tough test against Columbia

Kentucky digs out of biggest deficit of season to stay undefeated.

UK survives tough test against Columbia

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 11:38 p.m. EST December 10, 2014

UK's Aaron Harrison is fouled while shooting during the University of Kentucky men's basketball game against Columbia at Rupp Arena in Lexington, Ky. Wednesday, December 10, 2014. (Photo: , By Mike Weaver, Special to the CJ)

4 CONNECT 14 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. – That was unexpected. After routing nearly everyone it has played, the top-ranked University of Kentucky basketball team got a real challenge from visiting Columbia on Wednesday night at Rupp Arena.

The Wildcats needed more than five minutes to make a bucket, had to overcome their largest deficit of the season and didn't take their first lead until barely 13 minutes remained in the game. Kentucky finished strong, though, and slogged its way to a 56-46 victory to remain unbeaten.

"That hasn't really happened to us this year," sophomore shooting guard Aaron Harrison said, but "we're mature. We just had to settle down and start playing and it was fine after that."

Coach John Calipari was "happy" the Cats (10-0) played their closest game so far, because "it shows us" what happens when they come out flat. Recent shooting struggles continued – they hit just 36.7 percent from the field, only 2 for 17 from 3-point range – and they had a down defensive night, by their own lofty standards.

Columbia zipped it around, working the shot clock and waiting for an open shot, and hit eight 3-pointers to hang around all night.

MORE: Sullivan | Against UK, leads don't last

MORE: Game Rewind | UK survives Columbia's scare

Perhaps UK was bored coming off a 33-point win over Eastern Kentucky, its fifth margin of at least 30 this season, or looking ahead to Saturday's game against No. 21 North Carolina. Maybe the Wildcats were simply out of sync with freshman guards Tyler Ulis and Devin Booker sidelined by "minor injuries," which shelved the two-platoon plan for the night.

Whatever the reason, Columbia, a team that has lost games to Stony Brook and Loyola (Md.), gave Kentucky more of a battle than it bargained for. The Lions (5-3) roared out to a surprising 11-0 lead, hitting 4 of 7 shots to start while the Cats missed their first seven and turned it over three times quickly.

"You (need to) look at it in the sense of: This team's coming here to take your money or take your job or girlfriend," said Derek Willis, UK's 12th man who played a much larger role than anyone would've predicted. "You gotta motivate yourself, and it can be difficult, but you have to do it."

Kentucky, which barely trailed all season and never by so much, didn't score its first points until Aaron Harrison's driving layup and free throw with 14:55 to go in the first half. The lead swelled back to 14-3 and was still double digits, 17-7, eight minutes into the game.

Freshman Karl-Anthony Towns finally got UK going, igniting a 7-0 run with a swished jumper, emphatic block and dish to Willie Cauley-Stein for a three-point play. The Cats closed the gap but could not overtake Columbia before the break.

    Last SlideNext Slide

    Lions leading scorer Maodo Lo kept hitting timely 3-pointers – he made four and led all scorers with 16 points – to keep Kentucky at arm's length. Columbia hit five 3-pointers in the first 20 minutes against the nation's stingiest defense and led 25-23 at intermission.

    "See, that's what the platoons have done for us: it hides all that," Calipari said, "because instead of getting seven minutes of that, you get two."

    Naturally, Willis was the one who finally broke through. The sophomore forward who averaged just 6.4 minutes in the five games he'd played this season snared an offensive rebound and sank two free throws to give Kentucky its first lead, 36-34, with 13:18 to go in the game.

    Kentucky coach John Calipari talks about his team's slow start and eventual victory over Columbia in Rupp Arena

    That was part of a 7-0 burst, which Lo broke up with another 3-pointer to get the Lions within one – the last time the game was close. Kentucky launched an 18-4 run, punctuated by a Willis 3-pointer, for a 15-point lead with 1:39 to go.

    He and Harrison, who led the Cats with 14 points, hit the team's only shots beyond the arc as the perimeter struggle continued. Cauley-Stein helped steady Kentucky defensively in the second half and finished with 10 points and 10 rebounds.

    "Thank goodness we're a terrific defensive team," Calipari said, "because this isn't the first game we've shot the ball like this."

    Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
